quiz.name: Module 8: Equity Valuation: Concepts and Basic Tools
quiz.subtopic: Module 8: Equity Valuation: Concepts and Basic Tools

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-21
entry.itemBody: Asset-based valuation most likely uses estimates of the company's:

answerFeedback.686d86e7-1df1-4df7-8a2a-34297b5e1547: Incorrect because an asset-based valuation of a company uses estimates of the market or fair value of the company’s assets and liabilities.
answerFeedback.7c41cba3-e98c-4a3c-9e78-e93f14d011ac: Correct because an asset-based valuation of a company uses estimates of the market or fair value of the company’s assets and liabilities.
answerFeedback.d713ed4a-7b98-4faa-8edc-5df391e5b7bc: Incorrect because an asset-based valuation of a company uses estimates of the market or fair value of the company’s assets and liabilities.

choices.itemBody: C. assets, liabilities, and projected cash flow.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-13
entry.itemBody: A stock dividend:

answerFeedback.2bbc0719-72da-4568-bac9-a250ce7a13db: Correct because a stock dividend divides the “pie” (the market value of shareholders’ equity) into smaller pieces without affecting the value of the pie or any shareholder’s proportional ownership in the company.
answerFeedback.562daf33-a104-43c9-a10e-4a5a9547d88d: Incorrect because stock dividends are not relevant for valuation.
answerFeedback.8eaee99f-948f-46ba-947e-beef024b74b0: Incorrect because a stock dividend is a type of dividend in which a company distributes additional shares of its common stock (typically, 2%–10% of the shares then outstanding) to shareholders instead of cash. This results in an increase, not a reduction in the number of shares outstanding.

choices.itemBody: A. is relevant for valuation of a company.
B. involves a reduction in the number of shares outstanding.
C. does not affect the shareholders' proportional ownership in the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-McDonald-18
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, a reverse stock split results in:

answerFeedback.8c2e7383-cd5b-4a50-8813-e73cb31efb4e: Correct because a reverse stock split involves a reduction in the number of shares outstanding with a corresponding increase in share price.
answerFeedback.e8ac2318-abdf-4668-a3a3-b8e5fd572619: Incorrect because a reverse stock split involves a reduction in the number of shares outstanding with a corresponding increase in share price.
answerFeedback.f721d232-bd4f-481a-aea9-93e2a93c6a8d: Incorrect because this describes a stock split, not a reverse stock split. A stock split involves an increase in the number of shares outstanding with a consequent decrease in share price. A reverse stock split involves a reduction in the number of shares outstanding with a corresponding increase in share price.

choices.itemBody: A. a decrease in the number of shares and an increase in the share price.
B. an increase in the number of shares and a decrease in the share price.
C. an increase in the number of shares and an increase in the share price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-22
entry.itemBody: In dividend payment chronology, the ex-dividend date most likely comes after the:

answerFeedback.2a76d7a1-c2a6-400e-9270-dfbe7a85dc2f: Incorrect because the final milestone in the dividend payment chronology is the payment date (or payable date), which is the day that the company actually mails out (or electronically transfers) a dividend payment to shareholders.
answerFeedback.3523437f-1793-42b2-904d-68855051163d: Incorrect because ex-dividend date is followed closely (one or two business days later) by the holder-of-record date (also called the owner-of-record date, shareholder-of-record date, record date, date of record, or date of book closure), the date that a shareholder listed on the company’s books will be deemed to have ownership of the shares for purposes of receiving the upcoming dividend.
answerFeedback.fd2097b0-eaac-4d13-a0fd-c826a902894f: Correct because first is the declaration date, the day that the company issues a statement declaring a specific dividend. Next comes the ex-dividend date (or ex- date), the first date that a share trades without (i.e., “ex”) the dividend.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-20
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following are equivalent to stock dividends in terms of the economic effect on the company and shareholders?

answerFeedback.2f0d51da-92c1-4494-8a53-3eb446c1ff00: Incorrect because a cash dividend is a cash distribution made to a company’s shareholders. No cash flow from the company to the shareholders happen in case of a stock dividend. A stock dividend divides the “pie” (the market value of shareholders’ equity) into smaller pieces without affecting the value of the pie or any shareholder’s proportional ownership in the company. Thus, stock dividends are not relevant for valuation.
answerFeedback.5cc3ec9d-075f-4426-a5ca-07301981eaeb: Correct because a stock dividend divides the “pie” (the market value of shareholders’ equity) into smaller pieces without affecting the value of the pie or any shareholder’s proportional ownership in the company. Thus, stock dividends are not relevant for valuation. Stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders.
answerFeedback.c3fcd1a0-1975-4828-b491-ace8a426d191: Incorrect because a share repurchase (or buyback) is a transaction in which a company uses cash to buy back its own shares. A share repurchase is viewed as equivalent to the payment of cash dividends of equal value in terms of the effect on shareholders’ wealth, all other things being equal.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516112
entry.itemBody: A firm reports negative earnings for the year just ended. The price multiple of the firm’s stock that is least likely to be meaningful is:

answerFeedback.1ee58690-33c6-4a58-821e-f7e6f8c2489f: Incorrect. Alternative to negative trailing price-to-earnings ratio, practitioners may use leading price-to-earnings ratio by replacing last year’s loss with forecasted earnings which may be positive.
answerFeedback.ba6ad954-dc8a-45b0-ac58-16d552c8f86d: Correct. Negative earnings in the last year result in a negative ratio of trailing price to earnings and are not meaningful. Practitioners may use the ratio of (1) current price to cash flow or (2) leading price to earnings by replacing last year’s loss with forecasted earnings.
answerFeedback.c38d905a-5a52-4d54-bc20-fd8a18838a32: Incorrect. Alternative to negative trailing price-to-earnings ratio, practitioners may use price-to-cash-flow ratio because it is possible cash flow would be positive in spite of a small loss.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02947
entry.itemBody: A $25 par value non-callable, non-convertible preferred share pays an annual dividend rate of 5%. If the required rate of return is 4%, the preferred share's intrinsic value is closest to:

answerFeedback.5499568b-4b67-49fc-bd32-f0baf135a0da: Incorrect because it is the par value multiplied by the required return = 25 × (1 + 0.04) = $26.
answerFeedback.9d936777-50b3-40a6-b5a5-038a3c350768: Incorrect because it is equal to the par value + 1% (the difference between the 5% dividend and the 4% required return). 25 × (1 + (0.05 – 0.04)) = $25.25. Also, if a candidate mistakenly calculates V0 = (25 × 0.04) / 0.05 = $20.00, which is closest to this answer choice.
answerFeedback.a1e85af1-1376-4e9f-8f62-2c3ffb2523ba: Correct because the estimated intrinsic value (V0) is: , where D0 = dividend, and r = the required rate of return. The D0 = par value × annual dividend rate = $25 × 0.05 = $1.25.  V0 = $1.25 / 0.04 = $31.25.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03481
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's shares:

Dividend payable per share $0.50
Ex-date 20 August
Closing share price on 19 August $29.00

All else being equal, at the beginning of trading on 20 August, the company's shares will most likely trade at:

answerFeedback.442f6202-e741-403d-a9d7-c29a583631fa: Correct because the ex-dividend date (or ex-date) is the first date that a share trades without (i.e., 'ex') the dividend. Because buyers of a company's shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company's share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend. If the share trades at $29.00 on 19 August (the day before ex-date) and the upcoming dividend is $0.50, then all else being equal, the shares would trade at $28.50 ($29.00 - $0.50) on the ex-date.
answerFeedback.6eac708d-2277-45d5-8aa0-a7c496d580fd: Incorrect because $29.00 is the price of the share before the ex-date which is the last day purchasers will receive the upcoming dividend. All else being equal, the share price should trade below $29.00 and not at or above $29.00.
answerFeedback.a707b211-d0d5-41cf-9afc-52eafc6c094e: Incorrect because purchasers of shares on the ex-date or after the ex-date will not be entitled to the upcoming dividend and the share price should trade below $29.00 and not above $29.00. An uninformed candidate may confuse the dates and think that the share price on the ex-date should include dividends declared and inadvertently think that the 19 August share price doesn't include the dividend. Therefore the uninformed candidate adds $0.50 to the share price to arrive at $29.50.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03291
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and its common stock:

Forward P/E 8
Required rate of return 12%
Dividend growth rate 4%

Using the Gordon growth model, the company's dividend payout ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.784d7403-5465-465a-8c91-825e359362a1: Correct because according to the Gordon growth model equations P 0 = D 1 r−g and therefore P 0 E 1 = D 1 E 1 r−g = p r−g where E1 = forecast for next year's earnings, p = dividend payout ratio, D1 = forward dividend, r = required rate of return, and g = dividend growth rate, the dividend payout ratio p = 8.0 × (0.12 – 0.04) = 0.64 = 64%.
answerFeedback.a4a3081a-c32e-4bd6-b105-9f06959c4a7c: Incorrect because it confuses the dividend payout ratio with the dividend yield in the Gordon growth model equation resulting in: D1/P0 = r – g = 0.12 – 0.04 = 0.08 = 8%.
answerFeedback.f5ffe433-4db0-467e-b382-2c008ac50ae8: Incorrect because it confuses the dividend payout ratio as the dividend growth rate divided by the required rate of return, resulting in p = 0.04/0.12 ≈ 0.333 = 33%. This is also closest to the product of the forward P/E and the dividend growth rate: 8.0 × 0.04 = 0.32 = 32%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05500
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and the economy:

Current share price €36
Forward P/E ratio 22
Nominal risk-free rate 2.5%
Risk premium 6.0%
Expected retention rate 60%

The best estimate of the company's dividend growth rate is:

answerFeedback.2a69cded-b1fe-4ce9-92a4-f7f42e4b4927: Incorrect because it uses the current stock price instead of the P/E ratio to solve for g: 36 = 0.40 / (0.085 – g) and g = 0.0739 ≈ 7.4%.
answerFeedback.6673e891-5049-415a-bb23-edea690a27e9:
Correct because justified forward P/E = p / (r – g), where p = payout ratio = (1 – retention rate) and r = required rate of return = nominal risk-free rate + risk premium.

22 = (1 – 0.60) / ((0.025 + 0.06) – g).

22 = 0.40 / (0.085 – g) and g = 0.0668 ≈ 6.7%.
answerFeedback.a486af72-de91-4c8f-a3e8-5bf1affd18a1:
Incorrect because it uses the retention rate instead of the payout ratio;

22 = 0.60 / (0.085 – g) and g = 0.0577 or 5.8%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06690
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, an increase in which of the following most likely increases a company's enterprise value?

answerFeedback.09591a26-2eda-4c6a-b412-1c796e044cce: Correct because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments). Therefore, enterprise value increases with an increase in the market value of preferred stock.
answerFeedback.419a1321-e253-4030-97b7-5e8050e846f0: Incorrect because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments). Enterprise value increases with a decrease, not increase, in the market value of cash and investments.
answerFeedback.bcba6236-0b6a-4c04-a763-cce725aaac7c: Incorrect because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments). Enterprise value increases with an increase in the market value, not book value, of debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09325
entry.itemBody: Enterprise value is most likely associated with:

answerFeedback.21a3a81e-b6ba-47c4-96ae-036bae9ffc44: Incorrect because asset-based valuation models estimate intrinsic value of a common share from the estimated value of the assets of a corporation minus the estimated value of its liabilities and preferred shares. The estimated market value of the assets is often determined by making adjustments to the book value (synonym: carrying value) of assets and liabilities. The theory underlying the asset-based approach is that the value of a business is equal to the sum of the value of the business's assets.
answerFeedback.408fe1a2-b97b-48da-a2cf-14964b92d664: Correct because multiplier models are based chiefly on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples. Enterprise value (EV) multiples have the form (Enterprise value)/(Value of a fundamental variable). Two possible choices for the denominator are earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) and total revenue.
answerFeedback.ba439c7d-4ec3-48a6-a1f5-1fc721f4d1a7: Incorrect because present value models estimate the intrinsic value of a security as the present value of the future benefits expected to be received from the security. In present value models, benefits are often defined in terms of cash expected to be distributed to shareholders (dividend discount models) or in terms of cash flows available to be distributed to shareholders after meeting capital expenditure and working capital needs (free-cash-flow-to-equity models).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07900
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an industry and three comparable companies within the industry:

  Company 1 Company 2 Company 3 Industry Average
Price/sales 8.9 3.2 5.7 6.2
Price/book 5.7 2.6 2.3 4.7

Based only on this information, the most overvalued company is:

answerFeedback.5f968460-69b4-4973-82a4-ab5ae19fe436: Incorrect because the P/S and P/B of Company 3 are lower than those of both Company 1 and the industry average.
answerFeedback.742afe40-66a8-41dc-87e0-afb44463c76e: Incorrect because the P/S and P/B of Company 2 are lower than those of both Company 1 and the industry average.
answerFeedback.bf5ce00f-66c8-4bad-b481-813d2da2e8d2: Correct because Company 1's P/S and P/B are both the highest compared to those of its two peers and the industry average. All else being equal, high P/S and P/B multiples point to relatively expensive valuations. Therefore, in the absence of conflict between the indications given by P/S and P/B (as both measures are the highest for the same company), the company most likely to be overvalued is Company 1.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02086
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following book value information about a company and its common shares:

Inventories €20 million
Net fixed assets €80 million
Total assets €150 million
Total liabilities €90 million
Shares outstanding 4 million

The analyst estimates the market value of net fixed assets to be 125% of book value and the market value of inventories to be 90% of book value. If the stock is currently trading at €19.50 per share, the asset-based value per share is most likely:

answerFeedback.304ffdd7-ed8f-4254-b16b-cdaf2c506af1: Incorrect because the unadjusted, not adjusted, asset-based value per share is less than the market price: (Total assets – total liabilities) / shares outstanding = (150 – 90) / 4 = 15.00.
answerFeedback.3c2504aa-dd05-4505-adc4-04282a9e7f34: Incorrect because it double counts net fixed assets and inventories by adding the adjusted net fixed assets and subtracts the adjusted inventories without removing the unadjusted values from total assets: (Total assets + adjusted net fixed assets – adjusted inventories – total liabilities) / shares outstanding = (150 + (80 × 1.25) – (0.90 × 20) – 90) / 4 = (150 + 100 – 18 – 90) / 4 = 35.50. 35.50 is greater than the market price of 19.50.
answerFeedback.4b420f15-8f45-4f06-a50f-bf84ea4f4ba5: Correct because the asset-based per share value is: market value of assets less market value of liabilities = (Total assets + increase in net fixed assets – decrease in inventories – total liabilities) / shares outstanding = [(150 + ((80 × 1.25) – 80) + ((20 × 0.90) – 20) – 90)] / 4 = (150 + 20 – 2 – 90) / 4 = 19.50. This is the same as the market price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Coorey-05
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following has the same effect on shareholders' wealth as a cash dividend?

answerFeedback.2c839702-82f0-49fc-be5f-61e980330aa5: Correct because a share repurchase is viewed as equivalent to the payment of cash dividends of equal value in terms of the effect on shareholders’ wealth, all other things being equal.
answerFeedback.759a983c-30c9-44ba-b2b0-8acb597da1db: Incorrect because in contrast to stock dividends and stock splits, share repurchases are an alternative to cash dividend payments.
answerFeedback.c4668c4e-d782-4a3f-b0b8-871e7c9d967b: Incorrect because in contrast to stock dividends and stock splits, share repurchases are an alternative to cash dividend payments.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03206
entry.itemBody: Asset-based valuation models are most appropriate for companies with a high proportion of:

answerFeedback.2479225b-5ded-499c-ac63-acefc039c5e3: Incorrect because asset-based valuations work well for companies that do not have a high proportion of intangible or ‘off the books' assets.
answerFeedback.8aa3aa6a-6b58-4a91-9eba-460f9889d7c3: Correct because asset-based valuations work well for companies that do have a high proportion of current assets and current liabilities.
answerFeedback.b7076aa9-8134-49bd-ae33-752562d1c6c8: Incorrect because illiquid assets would not have easily determinable market (fair) values and would be very difficult to analyze using asset valuation methods.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-Hambusch-07
entry.itemBody: The dividend discount model assumes that dividends are paid:

answerFeedback.0aaab566-fea8-4faa-8a7b-42c4adc1f601: Correct because according to the dividend discount model, each year's dividend Dt is the expected dividend in year t, assumed to be paid at the end of the year.
answerFeedback.ddc32ec5-0981-4cf7-a962-3a798c8d2454: Incorrect because according to the dividend discount model, each year's dividend Dt is the expected dividend in year t, assumed to be paid at the end of the year, not at the beginning of each year.
answerFeedback.ed6d65ea-5cd7-47d6-9c5f-33845feb778e: Incorrect because according to the dividend discount model, each year's dividend Dt is the expected dividend in year t, assumed to be paid at the end of the year, not at the midpoint of each year.

choices.itemBody: C. at the end of each year.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Barker-04
entry.itemBody: When using a multiplier model, the fundamental variable is stated on:

answerFeedback.14f329e5-6194-4701-9d76-d47bccf9fc3c: Incorrect because the fundamental variable may be stated on a forward basis (e.g., forecasted EPS for the next year) or a trailing basis (e.g., EPS for the past year), as long as the usage is consistent across companies being examined.
answerFeedback.27d37e1c-8d10-4920-a524-1ec913a0b9f8: Correct because the fundamental variable may be stated on a forward basis (e.g., forecasted EPS for the next year) or a trailing basis (e.g., EPS for the past year), as long as the usage is consistent across companies being examined.
answerFeedback.5ee651a7-d3ea-4bd6-8116-6b93c6f1882a: Incorrect because the fundamental variable may be stated on a forward basis (e.g., forecasted EPS for the next year) or a trailing basis (e.g., EPS for the past year), as long as the usage is consistent across companies being examined.

choices.itemBody: C. either a trailing basis or a forward basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Grabe-10
entry.itemBody: A free-cash-flow-to-equity model is a(n):

answerFeedback.087fdc0b-6b9e-4ab0-a553-d27060bc62cc: Incorrect because a FCFE model is an example of a present value model, while asset-based valuation models estimate intrinsic value of a common share from the estimated value of the assets of a corporation minus the estimated value of its liabilities and preferred shares.
answerFeedback.8014706b-9c6b-4df5-bd14-194b515e79d6: Correct because present value models include free-cash-flow-to-equity models.
answerFeedback.baa747d6-4c33-4a96-b07b-3eb4c9bac66c: Incorrect because a FCFE model is an example of a present value model, while multiplier models are based chiefly on share price multiples or enterprise value multiples.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05965
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about common shares:

  Company Peer Group
Dividend payout ratio 40% 50%
Estimated future dividend growth rate 5% 4%

If the investor's required rate of return is 9%, the company's justified forward P/E is:

answerFeedback.1a7d5c50-fe2c-4f57-8897-e434d4521a3e: Incorrect because the company's justified forward P/E is not less than the peer group's justified forward P/E, but is the same. The company's justified forward P/E = p / (r – g) = 0.40 / (0.09 – 0.05) = 10.0. The peer group's justified forward P/E = 0.50 / (0.09 – 0.04) = 10.0. The candidate may select this response if they believe the company's lower payout ratio results in a lower P/E.
answerFeedback.77d9baa5-c45c-4253-aac3-6dad805dbe9d: Correct because the company's justified forward P/E is the same as the peer group's justified forward P/E. The company's justified forward P/E = p / (r – g) = 0.40 / (0.09 – 0.05) = 10.0. The peer group's justified forward P/E = 0.50 / (0.09 – 0.04) = 10.0.
answerFeedback.bdc9fe8b-e1a8-4594-9acf-e8db4322b2b5: Incorrect because the company's justified forward P/E is not greater than the peer group's justified forward P/E, but is the same. The company's justified forward P/E = p / (r – g) = 0.40 / (0.09 – 0.05) = 10.00. The peer group's justified forward P/E = 0.50 / (0.09 – 0.04) = 10.00. The candidate may select this response if they believe that the company's higher future dividend growth rate results in a higher P/E.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the peer group's justified forward P/E.
B. the same as the peer group's justified forward P/E.
C. greater than the peer group's justified forward P/E.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05012
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and its historical price multiples:

  Current Historical
EPS $3.00 ---
Cash flow per share $4.00 ---
Book value per share $40.00 ---
P/B ---   0.6
P/E --- 12.0
P/CF ---   8.0

Based only on this information, if the share price is $30, the company's shares are most likely overvalued based on:

answerFeedback.3ccd8549-9f1a-4929-9bf5-e2f38b7498dd: Incorrect because the P/E value for the company is $30 ⁄ $3 = 10, which is below the benchmark ratio of 12, indicating the shares are undervalued based on P/E (i.e. the ratio is lower than the benchmark).
answerFeedback.4ae3ce60-99bc-4595-92c5-1786a0b12047: Correct because the P/B value for the company is $30 ⁄ $40 = 0.75, which is above the benchmark ratio of 0.6, indicating the shares are overvalued based on P/B (i.e. the ratio is higher than the benchmark). Both the P/E and P/CF ratios for the company are below their benchmarks, and therefore are not overvalued on that basis.
answerFeedback.b493570a-b80e-4a99-a257-c33d39a9b3e9: Incorrect because the P/CF value for the company is $30 ⁄ $4 = 7.5, which is below the benchmark ratio of 8, indicating the shares are undervalued based on P/CF (i.e. the ratio is lower than the benchmark).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08318
entry.itemBody: A non-callable, non-convertible perpetual preferred share pays a level dividend of $1.20 with a current market price of $20. If an investor has a required rate of return of 6%, the preferred shares are most likely:

answerFeedback.3cc20822-25ee-4859-a2d1-68644ed0b199: Correct because the market price is equal to the calculated value based on the stated rate of return. Since the preferred share pays a perpetual level dividend, its value is V0 = D0/r = $1.20/0.06 = $20. If the estimated value equals the market price, the analyst infers the security is fairly valued.
answerFeedback.4f758896-f511-4420-87ae-744be4c1e1c2: Incorrect because the market price equals the calculated intrinsic value, implying the shares are not undervalued.
answerFeedback.792b1a09-10c0-4ddb-b0c5-4406d144b203: Incorrect because the market price equals the calculated intrinsic value, implying the shares are not overvalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09106
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company:

Estimated forward P/E ratio 8
Retention rate 45%

If the investor's required rate of return is 10%, the company's ROE is closest to:

answerFeedback.3027f2bd-76f8-474b-8ec4-49c3e3a021cd:
Correct because P0/E1 = p/(r – g), where g = b × ROE

Restating the equation we arrive at: P0/E1 = p/(r – (b × ROE)) where:

p = dividend payout ratio = (1 – retention rate) = (1 – b)

r = required rate of return on the stock

g = dividend growth rate = retention rate × ROE

Therefore, P0/E1 = p/(r – (b × ROE)) is rearranged as: P0/E1 = (1 – b)/(r – (b × ROE))

Rearranging this equation we arrive at: ROE = (((1 – b)/(P0/E1)) – r)/–b

ROE = (((1 – 45%)/8) – 10%)/–45% ≈ 6.9%.
answerFeedback.35f30055-e0db-4786-a9a4-dc344c213d5a: Incorrect because the retention rate and the dividend payout ratio have been interchanged. That is, arriving at this answer incorrectly applies 45% as the dividend payout ratio and applies 55% as the retention rate in the rearranged ROE calculation of: ROE = (((1 – b)/(P0/E1)) – r)/–b. That is, ROE is incorrectly calculated as: ROE = (((1 – 55%)/8) – 10%)/–55% ≈ 8.0%.
answerFeedback.c82cc7c0-023a-4ad9-842d-d5c9c23cc1af: Incorrect because instead of applying p, the dividend payout ratio, or (1 – b) in the numerator, the return ratio has been used in the numerator. That is, ROE was erroneously applied as, ROE = (((b)/(P0/E1)) – r)/–b. That is, ROE is mistakenly calculated as: ROE = (((45%)/8) – 10%)/–45% ≈ 9.7%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01229
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data for three companies in the same industry (in millions):

Company Enterprise Value (EV) Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, & Amortization (EBITDA)
1 $100 $8
2 $150 $10
3 $200 $15

Based on enterprise value multiples, which of the three companies is likely the most undervalued?

answerFeedback.248bc49a-7b13-4b1c-a3c3-0be9091211cd: Incorrect because Company 1's EV/EBITDA multiple is lower than either Company 2's or Company 3's multiple which indicates that Company 1 is likely the most undervalued of the three.
answerFeedback.8533abaf-8294-4d5a-829a-59c452dd5219:
Correct because EV is often viewed as the cost of a takeover and EBITDA is a proxy for operating cash flow. Companies with relatively low EV/EBITDA multiples are likely to be undervalued. Company 1 has the lowest EV/EBITDA multiple among the three.

Company 1: EV/EBITDA = 100,000,000 / 8,000,000 = 12.5;

Company 2: EV/EBITDA = 150,000,000 / 10,000,000 = 15.0;

Company 3: EV/EBITDA = 200,000,000 / 15,000,000 = 13.3.
answerFeedback.cb81fb49-addf-4d64-ac1c-2a6088477a1c: Incorrect because Company 1's EV/EBITDA multiple is lower than either Company 2's or Company 3's multiple which indicates that Company 1 is likely the most undervalued of the three.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01444
entry.itemBody: A company's perpetual preferred stock has a $100 par value and a $1.50 quarterly dividend. The required rate of return is 5%. The intrinsic value of the preferred stock is most likely:

answerFeedback.6aeecf0d-4dbd-48bd-beb0-f30bd657e0ee: Correct because the dividend yield is 6% ((4 × 1.50) / 100) which is higher than the required return (5%), so the preferred shares will be valued above par. Alternatively, the intrinsic value (V0) = D0 / r, where D0 is the preferred stock's constant annual dividend and r is the required rate of return. V0 = (4 × 1.50) / 0.05 = $120 which is higher than the par value.
answerFeedback.cfc0ffee-7c97-4e55-827b-39667b05d4da: Incorrect because for the preferred shares to be valued at par, the dividend yield must be equal to the required return.
answerFeedback.e5ef4df8-2f9a-4513-9d05-5e226ec6191d: Incorrect because for the preferred shares to be valued below par, the dividend yield must be lower than the required return.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 14JDB
entry.itemBody:
An analyst valuing a stock makes the following assumptions:

• the required return does not change,

• the dividend growth rate does not change,

• the dividend growth rate is less than the required return.

The most appropriate model to value this stock is the:

answerFeedback.023a204f-f6f7-4440-b1d1-d485e31d720d: Correct because the assumptions of the Gordon model are as follows: Dividends are the correct metric to use for valuation purposes; The dividend growth rate is forever: It is perpetual and never changes; The required rate of return is also constant over time; The dividend growth rate is strictly less than the required rate of return.
answerFeedback.93aff486-0a4e-430e-a20d-1ba585d1df95: Incorrect because a three-stage DDM, makes use of three growth rates: a high growth rate for an initial finite period, followed by a lower growth rate for a finite second period, followed by a lower, sustainable growth rate into perpetuity.
answerFeedback.99fcb3b1-0dc4-43dd-865b-5355432e10ee: Incorrect because the two-stage DDM thus makes use of two growth rates: a high growth rate for an initial, finite period followed by a lower, sustainable growth rate into perpetuity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05844
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company and its non-callable, non-convertible, perpetual preferred stock:

Estimated EPS growth rate 6.00%
Par value per share €25.00
Dividend per share (annual) €1.55

If the analyst estimates the intrinsic value to be €26.00 per share, the required rate of return is closest to:

answerFeedback.19c63d4c-3510-4766-8592-436f3135cac2: Correct because the intrinsic value of a non-callable, non-convertible, perpetual preferred share is: V0 = D0 / r. Solving for r = D0 / V0 = €1.55 / €26.00 ≈ 5.96%.
answerFeedback.4f7c1fb3-59c4-4080-a457-0f294b60e82d: Incorrect because it uses the par value instead of the analyst's estimated intrinsic value: r = D0 / par value = €1.55 / €25.00 = 0.062 = 6.20%.
answerFeedback.e0cf5f99-2a00-4b9c-ad53-13680a2ecc29: Incorrect because the dividend is increased by the EPS growth rate: D0 ×(1+g) / V0 = €1.55 × 1.06 / €26.00 = €1.643 / €26.00 ≈ 6.32%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01606
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a common stock:

Current dividend (D0) €1.10
Dividend growth rate: Years 1 and 2 15%
Dividend growth rate: Year 3 and beyond 3%
Required rate of return on equity 7%

The stock's intrinsic value is closest to:

answerFeedback.5c93256d-2561-4e11-99b4-b422a974845d:
Correct because the stock's value based on the multistage dividend discount model is as follows:

V0 = D0 × (1 + gS) / (1 + r) + D0 × (1 + gS)2 / (1 + r)2 + P2 / (1 + r)2

V0 = D0 × (1 + gS) / (1 + r) + D0 × (1 + gS)2 / (1 + r)2 + (D0 × (1 + gS)2 × (1 + gL) / (r – gL)) / (1 + r)2

V0 = (1.10 × 1.15) / 1.07 + (1.10 × 1.152) / 1.072 + ((1.10 × 1.152 × 1.03) / (0.07 – 0.03)) / 1.072

V0 = €35.17.

Where: V0 = intrinsic value of stock

Dt = dividend at time t

r = required rate of return

gS = dividend growth rate for year 1 and year 2

gL = dividend growth rate for year 3 and beyond.
answerFeedback.85024f0b-f3ba-4fd6-a221-7b161c9f80f1:
Incorrect because D0 is used as the year 1 dividend instead of D1:

V0 = D0 / (1 + r) + D1 / (1 + r)2 + P1 / (1 + r)2

V0 = D0 / (1 + r) + D1 / (1 + r)2 + (D2 / (r – gL)) / (1 + r)2

V0 = (1.10 / 1.07) + (1.10 × 1.15) / 1.072 + ((1.10 × 1.152) / (0.07 – 0.03)) / 1.072

V0= €33.90.
answerFeedback.86a37368-2815-4cd1-bea7-0fea89e0af24:
Incorrect because D2 is used instead of D3 in calculating P2.

V0 = D1 / (1 + r) + D2 / (1 + r)2 + P1 / (1 + r)2

V0 = D1 / (1 + r) + D2 / (1 + r)2 + (D2 / (r – gL)) / (1 + r)2

V0 = (1.10 × 1.15) / 1.07 + (1.10 × 1.152) / 1.072 + ((1.10 × 1.152) / (0.07 – 0.03)) / 1.072

V0 = €34.22.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09849
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following per share estimates for a company's stock:

Year 1 dividend (D1) $4.00
Year 2 dividend (D2) $4.40
Stock price at end of Year 2 $50.00

Using the dividend discount model, if the required rate of return is 10% and the stock's current market price is $50.00, the stock is most likely:

answerFeedback.52c2c473-f201-4ff0-a141-3c831fcbc6b4: Incorrect because the stock's intrinsic value ($48.60) is less than the current market price for the stock ($50.00). A candidate may mistake the relationship between value and price and incorrectly conclude that the stock is undervalued.
answerFeedback.6498a8b6-4759-4242-9593-6d46b57a8bf9: Incorrect because the stock's intrinsic value ($48.60) is less than the current market price for the stock ($50.00). A candidate may mistakenly select B on the basis that the stock price at the end of year 2 is the same as the stock's current market price.
answerFeedback.911a0938-3be7-43b4-997b-b79ce793d5f7:
Correct because using the dividend discount model, the stock's intrinsic value (V0) is given by: V0 = 

Where:

V0 = value of a share of stock today, at t = 0;

Dt = expected dividend in year t, assumed to be paid at the end of the year;

r = required rate of return on the stock

n = number of holding periods; in this case n = 2

Therefore, V0 = $4.00/(1+10%) + $4.40/(1+10%)2 + $50.00/(1+10%)2 = $3.64 + 3.64 + $41.32 = $48.60. Therefore the stock's intrinsic value is less than the current market price for the stock ($50.00) and as such the stock is considered overvalued. If the estimated value is less than the market price, the analyst infers the security is overvalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Equity-McDonald-15
entry.itemBody: The free-cash-flow-to-equity model:

answerFeedback.90039ed3-2e14-4f82-a742-7e570f4e9d60: Incorrect because net amounts borrowed (borrowings minus repayments) are considered to be available for distribution to common shareholders.
answerFeedback.c0271809-7d9c-409a-a7a6-60c5c784c6a5: Incorrect because in practice, many analysts prefer to use a free-cash-flow-to-equity (FCFE) valuation model. These analysts assume that dividend-paying capacity should be reflected in the cash flow estimates rather than expected dividends. FCFE is a measure of dividend-paying capacity.
answerFeedback.ef4fc7c8-47cb-4c21-913a-b1cb9fb859eb: Correct because analysts may also use FCFE valuation models for a non-dividend-paying stock.

choices.itemBody: B. can be used to value non-dividend paying stocks.
C. requires an estimate of future dividend payments.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Coorey-07
entry.itemBody: At which of the following days does a buyer of a company's shares first become no longer eligible to receive a dividend?

answerFeedback.2d1f0b2c-850a-473f-9318-70a37e38a072: Correct because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend.
answerFeedback.ef225936-a31e-4543-97d0-76719e557454: Incorrect because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend.
answerFeedback.f2909c9c-7a78-4322-a891-a086d1abc3e5: Incorrect because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10192
entry.itemBody: An advantage of using price multiples in valuation is most likely that multiples:

answerFeedback.1456e0b0-59f8-43c4-ae0c-94403e15a33c: Incorrect because differences in reporting rules among different markets and in chosen accounting methods can result in revenues, earnings, book values, and cash flows that are not easily comparable. These differences can, in turn, result in multiples that are not easily comparable.
answerFeedback.210010be-d0cb-474b-8431-824980a1dfc2: Incorrect because the multiples for cyclical companies may be highly influenced by current economic conditions.
answerFeedback.89a93300-3432-4081-8e56-7829085ab73e: Correct because the major advantage of using price multiples is that they allow for relative comparisons, both cross-sectional (versus the market or another comparable) and in time series. The approach can be especially beneficial for analysts who are assigned to a particular industry or sector and need to identify the expected best performing stocks within that sector. Price multiples are popular with investors because the multiples can be calculated easily and many multiples are readily available from financial websites and newspapers.

choices.itemBody: B. are not affected by differences in accounting rules.
C. for cyclical companies are relatively stable over the economic cycle.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q1

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The current market price of the stock exceeds the upper bound of the analyst’s estimate of the intrinsic value of the stock.

entry.itemBody: An analyst estimates the intrinsic value of a stock to be in the range of €17.85 to €21.45. The current market price of the stock is €24.35. This stock is most likely:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q2

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The market price is less than the estimated intrinsic, or fundamental, value.

entry.itemBody: An analyst determines the intrinsic value of an equity security to be equal to $55. If the current price is $47, the equity is most likely:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q3

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Asset-based valuation models calculate the intrinsic value of equity by subtracting liabilities from the market value of assets.

entry.itemBody: In asset-based valuation models, the intrinsic value of a common share of stock is based on the:

choices.itemBody: A. estimated market value of the company’s assets.
B. estimated market value of the company’s assets plus liabilities.
C. estimated market value of the company’s assets minus liabilities.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q4

feedback.neutral: C is correct. FCFE can be used in a form of present value, or discounted cash flow, model. Both EV and price to free cash flow are forms of multiplier models.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely used in a present value model?

choices.itemBody: B. Price to free cash flow.
C. Free cash flow to equity.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q5

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Multiplier valuation models (in the form of P/B) and asset-based valuation models (in the form of adjustments to book value) use book value, whereas present value models typically discount future expected cash flows.

entry.itemBody: Book value is least likely to be considered when using:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q6

feedback.neutral: B is correct. To use a discounted cash flow model, the analyst will require FCFE or dividend data. In addition, the analyst will need data to calculate an appropriate discount rate.

entry.itemBody: An analyst is attempting to calculate the intrinsic value of a company and has gathered the following company data: EBITDA, total market value, and market value of cash and short-term investments, liabilities, and preferred shares. The analyst is least likely to use:

choices.itemBody: B. a discounted cash flow model.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q7

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The FCFE model assumes that dividend-paying capacity is reflected in FCFE.

entry.itemBody: An analyst who bases the calculation of intrinsic value on dividend-paying capacity rather than expected dividends will most likely use the:

choices.itemBody: B. free cash flow to equity model.
C. cash flow from operations model.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q8

feedback.neutral: C is correct. According to the dividend discount model, the intrinsic value of a stock today is the present value of all future dividends. In this case, the intrinsic value is the present value of D 1, D 2, and P 2. Note that P 2 is the present value at Period 2 of all future dividends from Period 3 to infinity.

entry.itemBody: An investor expects to purchase shares of common stock today and sell them after two years. The investor has estimated dividends for the next two years, D 1 and D 2, and the selling price of the stock two years from now, P 2. According to the dividend discount model, the intrinsic value of the stock today is the present value of:

choices.itemBody: B. future expected dividends, D 1 and D 2.
C. future expected dividends and price—D 1, D 2 and P 2.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q9

feedback.neutral: A is correct. In the FCFE model, the intrinsic value of stock is calculated by discounting expected future FCFE to present value. No further adjustments are required.

entry.itemBody: In the free cash flow to equity (FCFE) model, the intrinsic value of a share of stock is calculated as:

choices.itemBody: A. the present value of future expected FCFE.
B. the present value of future expected FCFE plus net borrowing.
C. the present value of future expected FCFE minus fixed capital investment.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q10

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Dividend discount models can be used for a stock that pays a current dividend or a stock that is expected to pay a dividend. FCFE can be used for both of those stocks and for stocks that do not, or are not expected to, pay dividends in the near future. Both of these models are forms of present value models.

entry.itemBody: With respect to present value models, which of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. Present value models can be used only if a stock pays a dividend.
B. Present value models can be used only if a stock pays a dividend or is expected to pay a dividend.
C. Present value models can be used for stocks that currently pay a dividend, are expected to pay a dividend, or are not expected to pay a dividend.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q11

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The expected annual dividend is 4.80% × $25 = $1.20. The value of a preferred share is $1.20/0.0449 = $26.73.

entry.itemBody: A Canadian life insurance company has an issue of 4.80 percent, $25 par value, perpetual, non-convertible, non-callable preferred shares outstanding. The required rate of return on similar issues is 4.49 percent. The intrinsic value of a preferred share is closest to:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q12

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The required rate of return, r, can vary widely depending on the inputs and is not unique. A preferred stock with a constant dividend would not have a growth rate to estimate, and the investor’s time horizon would have no effect on the calculation of intrinsic value.

entry.itemBody: Two analysts estimating the value of a non-convertible, non-callable, perpetual preferred stock with a constant dividend arrive at different estimated values. The most likely reason for the difference is that the analysts used different:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q13

feedback.neutral: C is correct. P 0 = D 1/(r – g) = 1.75(1.092)/(0.123 – 0.092) = $61.65.

entry.itemBody: The Beasley Corporation has just paid a dividend of $1.75 per share. If the required rate of return is 12.3 percent per year and dividends are expected to grow indefinitely at a constant rate of 9.2 percent per year, the intrinsic value of Beasley Corporation stock is closest to:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q14

feedback.neutral: C is correct. According to the Gordon growth model, V 0 = D 1/(r – g). In this case, D 1   = $2.00 × 1.04 = $2.08, so V 0 = $2.08/(0.07 – 0.04) = $69.3333 = $69.33.

entry.itemBody: An investor is considering the purchase of a common stock with a $2.00 annual dividend. The dividend is expected to grow at a rate of 4 percent annually. If the investor’s required rate of return is 7 percent, the intrinsic value of the stock is closest to:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q18

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The Gordon growth model (also known as the constant growth model) can be used to value dividend-paying companies in a mature phase of growth. A stable dividend growth rate is often a plausible assumption for such companies.

entry.itemBody: The Gordon growth model can be used to value dividend-paying companies that are:

choices.itemBody: A. expected to grow very fast.
B. in a mature phase of growth.
C. very sensitive to the business cycle.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q36

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Very small changes in inputs, such as required rate of return or dividend growth rate, can result in large changes to the valuation model output. Some present value models, such as FCFE models, can be used to value companies without dividends. Also, the intrinsic value of a security is independent of the investor’s holding period.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely considered a weakness of present value models?

choices.itemBody: A. Present value models cannot be used for companies that do not pay dividends.
B. Small changes in model assumptions and inputs can result in large changes in the computed intrinsic value of the security.
C. The value of the security depends on the investor’s holding period; thus, comparing valuations of different companies for different investors is difficult.

entry.title: CFA0166-Q15

feedback.neutral:
A is correct. The current price of €22.56 is less than the intrinsic value (V 0) of €24.64; therefore, the stock appears to be currently undervalued. According to the two-stage dividend discount model:

V 0 = ∑ t = 1 n D 0 ( 1 + g S ) t ( 1 + r ) t + V n ( 1 + r ) n and V n = D n + 1 r − g L

 

  • Dn +1 = D 0(1 + gS ) n (1 + gL )
  • D 1 = €1.60 × 1.09 = €1.744
  • D 2 = €1.60 × (1.09)2 = €1.901
  • D 3 = €1.60 × (1.09)3 = €2.072
  • D 4 = €1.60 × (1.09)4 = €2.259
  • D 5 = [€1.60 × (1.09)4](1.04) = €2.349
  • V 4 = €2.349/(0.12 – 0.04) = €29.363
  • V 0 = 1.744 ( 1.12 ) 1 + 1.901 ( 1.12 ) 2 + 2.072 ( 1.12 ) 3 + 2.259 ( 1.12 ) 4 + 29.363 ( 1.12 ) 4
  •  = 1.557 + 1.515 + 1.475 + 1.436 + 18.661
  •  = €24.64 (which is greater than the current price of €22.56)

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The Gordon growth model is best suited to valuing mature companies. The two-stage model is best for companies that are transitioning from a growth stage to a mature stage. The three-stage model is appropriate for young companies just entering the growth phase.

entry.itemBody: The best model to use when valuing a young dividend-paying company that is just entering the growth phase is most likely the:

entry.title: CFA0166-Q20

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The company is a mature company with a steadily growing dividend rate. The two-stage (or multistage) model is unnecessary because the dividend growth rate is expected to remain stable. Although an FCFE model could be used, that model is more often chosen for companies that currently pay no dividends.

Omega is in a mature industry, and both its earnings and dividends are expected to grow at a rate of 3 percent annually. feedback.neutral:

These multiples are often specific to a company’s industry or sector and include price-to-sales and price-to-cash flow.

entry.itemBody: An analyst makes the following statement: “Use of P/E and other multiples for analysis is not effective because the multiples are based on historical data and because not all companies have positive accounting earnings.” The analyst’s statement is most likely:

choices.itemBody: A. inaccurate with respect to both historical data and earnings.
B. accurate with respect to historical data and inaccurate with respect to earnings.
